case_name: Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1958 filed by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated October 4, 1956 in I.T.A. No. 49 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 4, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.A. No. 49 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant Homi Jehangir Gheesta assessed to income-tax for 1946-47 on total income of Rs. 87,500 under s. 23(3) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1946-47 the appellant Homi Jehangir Gheesta was assessed to income-tax on a total income of Rs. 87,500 under s. 23 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: M. H. Sanjana, maternal grandfather of appellant, died on or about May 10, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that M. H. Sanjana, maternal grand father of the appellant, died on or about May 10, 1920.

facts.text: Litigation between Sanjana's widow Cursetbai and daughter Bai Jerbanoo (appellant's mother) about validity of will, compromised with mother getting one-third share in estate worth about Rs. 9,88,000.

anchor.surface_text: There was litigation between his widow Cursetbai and Bai Jerbanoo, Sanjanas daughter by his first wife, about the validity of a will left by Sanjana. Bai Jerbanoo was the appellants mother. The litigation was companypromised and the appellants mother got one-third share in the estate left by Sanjana the total value of which estate was about Rs. 9,88,000.

facts.text: Bai Jerbanoo (appellant's mother) died in 1933, leaving husband Jehangirji (father), son Homi (appellant), and daughter Aloo.

anchor.surface_text: Bai Jerbanoo died in 1933, leaving her husband Jehangirji  appellants father , her son Homi  appellant  and a daughter named Aloo.

facts.text: Bai Jerbanoo left estate worth about Rs. 2,10,000 (stated but no evidence).

anchor.surface_text: It was stated, though there was numberevidence thereof, that Bai Jerbanoo left an estate worth about Rs. 2,10,000 when she died.

facts.text: Appellant was minor at time of mother's death; his share of estate was Rs. 70,000.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a minor at the time of his mothers death. He had two uncles then, Phirozeshaw and Kaikhusroo. Phirozeshaw was the eldest member of the family. On his mothers death the appellants share of the estate was Rs. 70,000.

facts.text: Phirozeshaw (uncle) took charge of appellant's Rs. 70,000 share and made investments.

anchor.surface_text: Phirozeshaw took charge of it and made investments.

facts.text: Phirozeshaw died on December 12, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: He died on December 12, 1945.

facts.text: Kaikhusroo (uncle, executor of Phirozeshaw's will) found packet containing high denomination currency notes of Rs. 87,500 labelled with appellant's name in Phirozeshaw's safe.

anchor.surface_text: Kaikhusroo, younger brother of Phirozeshaw and one of the executors of his will, took charge of the estate of Phirozeshaw. When he opened a safe belonging to Phirozeshaw he found a packet with the name of the appellant on it. That packet companytained high denomination currency numberes of the value of Rs. 87,500.

facts.text: Appellant tendered Rs. 87,500 notes for encashment on January 24, 1946, with declaration that it was legacy from mother invested by father and late uncle Phirozeshaw.

anchor.surface_text: On January 24, 1946, the appellant tendered those numberes for encashment and made a declaration which was then necessary and in the declaration he said Legacy from my mother who died in 1933 when I was minor and money whereof was invested from time to time by my father and late uncle Phirozeshaw who recently died.

facts.text: Appellant submitted nil income return for relevant year when noticed by ITO.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant received a numberice from the Income-tax Officer to submit a return of his income for the relevant year, he submitted a return showing nil income.

facts.text: In letter dated January 7, 1947, appellant stated uncle Phirozeshaw handed over Rs. 87,500 to him and father before Phirozeshaw's death.

anchor.surface_text: When asked about the high denomination numberes which he had uncashed, he said in a letter dated January 7, 1947, that his uncle Phirozeshaw who used to manage his estate during his minority handed over to him and his father the sum of Rs. 87,500 sometime before his  i. e., Phirozeshaws  death in 1945.

facts.text: Appellant filed affidavit before ITO on September 29, 1949 containing contradictory statements.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also filed an affidavit before the Income-tax Officer on September 29, 1949, which also companytained companytradictory statements.

facts.text: ITO treated Rs. 87,500 as income from undisclosed source and assessed accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the materials before him, the Income- tax Officer did number accept the case of the appellant but came to the companyclusion that the true nature of the receipt of Rs. 87,500 was number disclosed. He treated the amount as appellants income from some source number disclosed and assessed him accordingly.

facts.text: Appeal to Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, who upheld ITO's conclusion after taking statements.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax. At the appellate stage the statements of the appellants father and uncle were taken by the Income-tax Officer, D-11 Ward, Bombay, and a further statement of the appellants uncle Kaikhusroo was taken by the appellate authority. That authority came to the same companyclusion as the Income-tax Officer had companye to.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld assessment by order dated October 7, 1955, noting discrepancies in appellant's stories.

anchor.surface_text: It dismissed the appeal by its Order dated October 7, 1955.

facts.text: Tribunal refused reference to High Court on March 8, 1956 under s.66 IT Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that numberquestion of law arose out of its order dated October 7, 1955, and by its order dated March 8, 1956, dismissed the application of the appellant for a reference under s. 66 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Bombay High Court summarily dismissed petition under s.66(2) on October 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant unsuccessfully moved the Bombay High Court by means of a petition under s. 66 2 . This petition was summarily dismissed by the High Court on October 4, 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on December 3, 1956 from High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a petition for special leave to appeal to this Court. By an order dated December 3, 1956, this Court granted Special Leave to Appeal to this Court from the order of the Bombay High Court dated October 4, 1956

facts.text: Bai Aloo (sister) received Rs. 85,000 from uncle Phirozeshaw before his death, submitted return but no assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Bai Aloo herself made a statement before the Income-tax Officer, D-II Ward, Bombay, on February 22, 1952, in which she indicated the cir- cumstances how she also received a sum of Rs. 85,000 from her uncle Phirozeshaw before the latters death. She further stated that she also submitted a return to the Income-tax Officer but was number subjected to any assessment on the sum received.

facts.text: Father summoned by ITO on June 23, 1950 but failed to comply initially.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal stated in its order that a summons was issued to the father by the Income-tax Officer to appear before the latter on June 23, 1950. The father failed to companyply with the summons.

facts.text: Appellant was student between 1943 and 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We were also told that the assessee was taking his education between 1943 and 1950 and as such he bad numberopportunity to earn any income.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no question of law arose from Tribunal order, upheld High Court dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we are of the view that numberquestion of law arose from the order of the Tribunal and we see numbergrounds for interference with the judgment and order of the Bombay High Court, dated October 4, 1956.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 4, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.A. No. 49 of 1956.
under s. 23 3  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
under s. 66 of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: was the High Court right in summarily rejecting the petition under s. 66(2)?

anchor.surface_text: was the High Court right in summarily rejecting the petition under s. 66  2  ?

issues.text: did the order of the Tribunal dated October 7, 1955, on the face of it raise any question of law?

anchor.surface_text: In other words, did the order of the Tribunal dated October 7, 1955, on the face of it raise any question of law ?

issues.text: whether the Tribunal arrived at its decision by considering material which is irrelevant to the enquiry, or by considering material which is partly relevant and partly irrelevant, or bases its decision partly on conjectures, surmises and suspicions

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it has been argued that the principles laid down by this Court in Dhirajlal Girdharilal Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  1  apply, because though the decision of the  1   1954  26 I. T. R. 736. Tribunal is final on a question of fact, an issue of law arises if the Tribunal arrives at its decision by companysider- ing material which is irrelevant to the enquiry, or by companysidering material which is partly relevant and partly irrelevant, or bases its decision partly on companyjectures, surmises and suspicions.

issues.text: in a case like the one before us the Department was required to prove by direct evidence that the sum of Rs. 87,500 was income in the hands of the appellant, or whether by mere rejection of the explanation of the assessee, the character of a particular receipt as income can be said to have been established where the circumstances of the rejection are such that the only proper inference is that the receipt must be treated as income

anchor.surface_text: It has also been argued before us that even if the explanation of the appellant as to the sum of Rs. 87,500 is number accepted, the Department did number prove by any direct evidence that the amount was income in the hands of the appellant. We do number think that in a case like the one before us the Department was required to prove by direct evidence that the sum of Rs. 87,500 was income in the hands of the appellant. Indeed, we agree that it is number in all cases that by mere rejection of the explanation of the assessee, the character of a particular receipt as income can be said to have been established but where the circumstances of the rejection are such that the only proper inference is that the receipt must be treated as income in the bands of the assessee, there is numberreason why the assessing authorities should number draw such an inference.

arguments.claim: Principles from Dhirajlal Girdharilal apply because Tribunal's decision is final on fact but issue of law arises if Tribunal considers irrelevant material, partly relevant/irrelevant material, or bases decision on conjectures, surmises, suspicions

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it has been argued that the principles laid down by this Court in Dhirajlal Girdharilal Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay (1) apply, because though the decision of the Tribunal is final on a question of fact, an issue of law arises if the Tribunal arrives at its decision by consi

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that on the face of it the decision of the Tribunal suffers from all the three defects mentioned above.

It is conten

court_response_anchor.surface_text: According to learned Counsel this showed that, the finding of the Tribunal was companyoured by prejudice. We are unable to agree. Even if it be taken

arguments.court_reasoning: Relevant for judging probability of story about mother's estate shares

anchor.surface_text: and Bai Aloo herself made a statement before the Income-tax Officer... she also received a sum of Rs. 85,000... no assessment... relevant consideration as to why Phirozeshaw did not hand over the money to Bai Aloo... in favour of appellant

court_response_anchor.surface_text: According to learned Counsel this showed that, the finding of the Tribunal was companyoured by prejudice. We are unable to agree. Even if it be taken

arguments.court_reasoning: Fact no assessment on Bai Aloo does not make story more probable

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Tribunal is wrong in this respect, we do number think that it is a matter of any companysequence. We must read the order of the Tribunal as a whole t

arguments.court_reasoning: Even if wrong, no consequence to main issue of source explanation; no evidence of mother's estate value or investments

arguments.claim: Even if appellant's explanation rejected, Department must prove by direct evidence that amount is income

court_response_anchor.surface_text: udice. Learned Counsel for the appellant has taken us through the entire order of the Tribunal as also the relevant materials on which it is based. Ha

arguments.court_reasoning: Not required in all cases; where rejection circumstances permit only inference of income, assessing authorities can draw such inference of fact

arguments.claim: No question of law arose from Tribunal order; High Court right to dismiss s.66(2) petition

anchor.surface_text: The short point for consideration is thiswas the High Court right in summarily rejecting the petition under s. 66(2)? In other words, did the order of the Tribunal dated October 7, 1955, on the face of it raise any question of law?

arguments.claim: Tribunal order not vitiated by irrelevant considerations, conjectures etc. per Dhirajlal; must read as whole

anchor.surface_text: We must read the order of the Tribunal as a whole to determine whether every material fact... has been considered fairly... whether the conclusion reached by the Tribunal has been coloured by irrelevant considerations or matters of prejudice.

Omar Salay Mohamed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: We have, in these circumstances, no hesitation whatever in holding that the assessee has miserably failed to explain satisfactorily the source of the sum of Rs. 87,500. It is properly taxed as income.

arguments.claim: True nature of receipt of Rs. 87,500 not disclosed; treat as income from undisclosed source

He treated the amount as appellant's income from some source not disclosed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay  1  or Omar Salay Mohamed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 . We must make

holdings.text: No question of law arose from the order of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we are of the view that no question of law arose from the order of the Tribunal and we see no grounds for interference with the judgment and order of the Bombay High Court, dated October 4, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's order, read as a whole, fairly considered material without irrelevant considerations, conjectures, or prejudice; discrepancies in assessee's explanations justify rejection.

holdings.text: High Court was right in summarily rejecting the petition under s.66(2).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we are of the view that no question of law arose from the order of the Tribunal and we see no grounds for interference with the judgment and order of the Bombay High Court, dated October 4, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No grounds for interference as Tribunal's factual findings final and not vitiated by legal error.

holdings.text: Tribunal's order not vitiated by considering irrelevant material, partly relevant/irrelevant material, or basing decision on conjectures, surmises, suspicions per Dhirajlal principles.

anchor.surface_text: Having examined the order of the Tribunal and those materials, we are unable to agree with learned Counsel for the appellant that the order of the Tribunal is vitiated by any of the defects adverted to in Dhirajlal Girdharilal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay or Omar Salay Mohamed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order read as whole shows fair consideration of discrepancies and probabilities; specific points raised by appellant (Bai Aloo, summons, student status etc.) relevant or immaterial.

holdings.text: Department not required to prove by direct evidence that receipt is income; where circumstances of rejecting assessee's explanation permit only proper inference that receipt is income, assessing authorities may draw such inference of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in a case like the one before us the Department was required to prove by direct evidence that the sum of Rs. 87,500 was income in the hands of the appellant. Indeed, we agree that it is not in all cases that by mere rejection of the explanation of the assessee, the character of a particular receipt as income can be said to have been established but where the circumstances of the rejection are such that the only proper inference is that the receipt must be treated as income in the hands of the assessee, there is no reason why the assessing authorities should not draw such an inference. Such an inference is an inference of fact and not of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not in every case mere rejection suffices, but where only inference possible is income, treat as such; applies here given assessee's failure to explain source satisfactorily.

holdings.text: Tribunal orders not to be examined sentence by sentence through a microscope to find minor lapses as peg for question of law.

anchor.surface_text: we do not think that those decisions require that the order of the Tribunal must be examined sentence by sentence, through a microscope as it were, so as to discover a minor lapse here or an incautious opinion there to be used as a peg on which to hang an issue of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretation of Dhirajlal and Omar Salay: review order as whole for vitiation, not microscopic.

holdings.text: Considerations regarding Bai Aloo's share and non-payment on majority/marriage relevant to probability of assessee's story.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the circumstances referred to by the Tribunal in connection with Bai Aloo's statement were irrelevant. What the Tribunal had to consider was the correctness or otherwise of a story in which the mother was stated to have left Rs. 2,10,000 out of which the heirs got one third share each. The Tribunal had to consider each aspect of the story in order to judge of its probability and from that point of view it was a relevant consideration as to why Bai Aloo's money was not paid when she became major or when she got married.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relevant for assessing overall probability of mother's estate story; no assessment on sister immaterial.

holdings.text: Father's failure to comply with summons does not vitiate Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this circumstance vitiates the order of the Tribunal which was based on grounds much more substantial than the failure of summons issued against him. The father was actually examined later and his statements were taken into consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order based on substantial discrepancies; father examined later.

holdings.text: Lack of explanation why uncle took charge when father alive is relevant consideration.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that this circumstance was also a relevant consideration, and if the father was in a position to give an explanation, he should have done so when he made his statement before the Income-tax Officer, D-11 Ward, Bombay, on February 8,1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Father should have explained in statement.

holdings.text: Even if assessee proved student status till 1950, makes no difference to main issue of source explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be taken that the appellant satisfactorily proved that he was a student till 1950, we do not think that it makes any real difference as to the main question at issue, which was whether the appellant received the sum of Rs. 70,000 from the estate of his mother, later increased by investments to Rs. 87,500 in 1945.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of mother's estate value or investments; irrelevant to source failure.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in a case like the one before us the Department was required to prove by direct evidence that the sum of Rs. 87,500 was income in the hands of the appellant. Indeed, we agree that it is not in all cases that by mere rejection of the explanation of the assessee, the character of a particular receipt as income can be said to have been established but where the circumstances of the rejection are such that the only proper inference is that the receipt must be treated as income in the hands of the assessee, there is no reason why the assessing authorities should not draw such an inference. Such an inference is an inference of fact and not of law.

We do not think that in a case like the one before us the Department was required to prove by direct evidence that the sum of Rs. 87,500 was income in the hands of the appellant. Indeed, we agree that it is not in all cases that by mere rejection of the explanation of the assessee, the character of a particular receipt as income can be said to have been established but where the circumstances of the rejection are such that the only proper inference is that the receipt must be treated as income in the hands of the assessee, there is no reason why the assessing authorities should not draw such an inference. Such an inference is an inference of fact and not of law.

we do not think that those decisions require that the order of the Tribunal must be examined sentence by sentence, through a microscope as it were, so as to discover a minor lapse here or an incautious opinion there to be used as a peg on which to hang an issue of law.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that the circumstances referred to by the Tribunal in connection with Bai Aloo's statement were irrelevant. What the Tribunal had to consider was the correctness or otherwise of a story in which the mother was stated to have left Rs. 2,10,000 out of which the heirs got one third share each. The Tribunal had to consider each aspect of the story in order to judge of its probability and from that point of view it was a relevant consideration as to why Bai Aloo's money was not paid when she became major or when she got married.
